entry.title: ğŸ˜² A Late Dream
entry.content:
was it a vision, or a waking dream?
fled is that music:â€”do I wake or sleep?
â€”Keats

She shut her eyes upon her bed,
And beauty glows about;
The beam of glamour â€˜round her head,
A bard could only doubt.

She lays on bed a nakÃ¨d wise:
And I am standing by;
â€”To feel the wishes in her eyes
The world I would defy.

The head upon my shoulder seeks
To think it carefully;
But lo!â€”how blushful are her cheeks:
I lay down carelessly.

Her damask lips grow fairer still
â€”Like cherry dews herself;
The soft white bosom, like a hill,
Is plump upon this elf.

The eyes of ink, and hair of silk
Have found their place on me;
Complexion hers is white as milk,
My eyesight leaves not she.

The falls of ink upon her head
Doth flow like inmost dream:
â€”the lock of hair that half abed
How sleek and smooth doth seem!

Her eyes emit voracious lust,
A lust that I obey:
For with an ardour full robust,
Beside her I do lay.

My arms then â€˜round her breasts doth twine
And mouth agapÃ¨d wide;
My hands then claspÃ¨d â€˜round the shrine
Behind her bras untiâ€™d.

Her legs curl upwards slightly bent,
And gapeth wide apart;
She nods her head and gave consent
For me to make a start.

I hold her hands and grab her knee,
As quick as lightâ€™ningâ€™s leap;
But looking up I see not she:
A shadow nigh me creep.

My mind then mocks my boyishness:
I was in dreamland deep!
That little nymph who dwells in me
Had lullÃ¨d me asleep!

I open my unwilling eyes
Towards the rising beam:
If I should die with her anigh
â€”How well such dying seem!
entry.summary: was it a vision, or a waking dream? fled is that music:â€”do I wake or sleep? â€”Keats

entry.title: ğŸŒ• Dear Queen Moon
entry.content:
Raindrops fiercer
Can never stop her:
The rising of the
Dear Queen Moon.

Sun hides thither,
Birds chirp yonder,
â€”all just for the
Dear Queen Moon.

Night grew darker,
But glows all â€˜round her,
For she is our
Dear Queen Moon.

Watch her closer:
Above the heather,
Where stars â€˜round cluster
Dear Queen Moon.

Manyâ€™s lover,
Than beauty fairer;
Selene we hight her:
Dear Queen Moon.

Sing together,
Dance forever;
For we are under
Dear Queen Moon.
entry.summary: Raindrops fiercer Can never stop her: The rising of the Dear Queen Moon.

entry.title: ğŸ§³ To a Friend on an Expedition

link.title: ğŸ§³ To a Friend on an Expedition

entry.content:
â€”how is andy tireless?

The team is weary in the green
Of finding scenes unseen;
We hadnâ€™t even strength to speak:
We limpÃ¨d nigh asleep.

Nor had I the heart to check
Yon pathways spick and speck;
Yet had he the strength to seek
Yon hidden mountain-peek.

entry.title: ğŸ¥² Lockdown
entry.content:
During the lockdown dull and dim,
I took a walk nearby;
Sipping a tea by glassâ€™ brim,
Cars passÃ¨d by and by.

Unto the heavens clear and bright,
My spirit went with sight;
And did the beaming sun well-nigh
Heedfully hear me sigh:

â€” â€˜Is it so that we oâ€™ercame
Virus who sickens all?
Or is it so its fiery flame,
Has made our lives seem small?â€™
entry.summary: During the lockdown dull and dim, I took a walk nearby; Sipping a tea by glassâ€™ brim, Cars passÃ¨d by and by.

entry.title: âš—ï¸ To Chemistry
entry.content:
â€”for it exhausts my spirit

I bid thee farewell fair and well,
Thou fiend in high estate:
The ruthless mien wherewith you dwell,
Gold you electroplate.

Ere lilies within herbage hide,
As wintry wind unfold;
Songbirds songless on trees abide,
Their grief and woe untold;

Ere the wondrous world close its eyes
â€”And poets miss their call,
I challenge thee who torment me:
Moles and molecules all.

With fancies gazing spirits high,
Thy carbon compounds die;
And thine own deathbed drawing nigh
â€”â€™Tis the triumph oâ€™ faerie skies.

entry.title: ğŸ© The Fallacy of Being â€˜Apoliticalâ€™

link.title: ğŸ© The Fallacy of Being â€˜Apoliticalâ€™

entry.content:
It is, I am given to understand, no new nor profound knowledge that everything in human world is, to some degree, political. Politics, at the root level, is just opinions whereby one endeavours to derive policy from; therefore, just like a living human being cannot â€˜have no opinionâ€™, he cannot be â€˜whole-heartedly apoliticalâ€™. A parallel apparent truth is that all men, however isolated from society, remains a social animal; and again cannot be entirely apolitical. For, however he who dwells in the innermost of the wilderness should shun it, the very act of isolating himself by escaping society and politics is one of the purest and most symbolic political acts.

Whereas from that which I observe lately many do not believe so. Some fail to rememberâ€”often deliberatelyâ€”this most familiar axiom of human nature, which should have been rooted-deeply already in every one of our souls since Aristotle, at least. A late exemplar can be easily seen should you go to websites of React.js, PyTorch and so forthâ€”an often criticised banner can be seen: â€˜Support Ukraine ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦, Help Provide Humanitarian Aid to Ukraine. â€˜ it says. The criticisers claim that tech should be free from politics, thus such act of trying to help victims of war out is to be condemned.

Well, then, if one must not participate in political activities, how does he achieve that?

Following the sound reasoning of why organisations must not express their political views from criticisers, their answer to this questions is yet simple: be blind. The aforementioned forgetfulness often involves the notion of disregarding reality; that is, to remark nothing upon the inconstant phantasmagorias that should soon pass as a dream before you: work nothing out of it, reflect nothing upon the matter, better see nothing of it, and most importantly keep the, as the old proverb goes, â€˜golden silenceâ€™. These very sound arguments may be deemed sagacious and learned till we should examine their emptinessâ€”what, for instance, is all this rigmarole about facing the changes of modern world with no reactions but a more pompous way of phrasing conservatism? how, I ask, is all this gibberish about keeping silent better than â€˜donâ€™t ask, donâ€™t tellâ€™?

To say that â€˜I am apoliticalâ€™, is nothing less political than saying â€˜I stand with Ukraineâ€™â€”for it is indeed opinions and statements which construct politics, and the assertion above is both.
entry.summary: It is, I am given to understand, no new nor profound knowledge that everything in human world is, to some degree, political. Politics, at the root level, is just opinions whereby one endeavours to derive policy from; therefore, just like a living human being cannot â€˜have no opinionâ€™, he cannot be â€˜whole-heartedly apoliticalâ€™. A parallel apparent truth is that all men, however isolated from society, remains a social animal; and again cannot be entirely apolitical. For, however he who dwells in the innermost of the wilderness should shun it, the very act of isolating himself by escaping society and politics is one of the purest and most symbolic political acts.

entry.title: ğŸ¤Œ The Usage of â€˜That Whichâ€™

link.title: ğŸ¤Œ The Usage of â€˜That Whichâ€™

entry.content:
â€˜that whichâ€™

  • thatÂ is a pronoun referring back to a noun phrase
  • whichÂ is the relative pronoun used for inanimate antecedents.

to put it simply, in â€˜a be that which c [verb]â€™, that refers to â€˜aâ€™, whilst â€˜whichâ€™ refers to â€˜thatâ€™. for instance

a very small part of acting is that which takes place on stage

is the same as

a very small part of acting is acting which takes place on stage

which equates

a very small part of acting is what takes place on stage (..informal)

for the ones who does not like the usage of â€˜whichâ€™, â€˜that whichâ€™ can also be â€˜that thatâ€™: â€˜the latent opposition to rearming Germany is as strong as that that has found public expression.â€™ (from â€˜The Careful Writerâ€™ by Per Bernstein, â€˜Let it be noted that there are two exceptions to the use ofÂ thatÂ to introduce a defining clause. One is a situation in which the demonstrativeÂ thatÂ and the relativeÂ thatÂ come together, as in this sentence:Â â€¦[the example from above]â€¦ â€˜, â€˜the second exception is a situation in which the relative follows a preposition: for example,Â of which,Â notÂ of that.â€™)

some definitions that might help:

inanimate

â€˜inanimateâ€™ (or â€˜non-animateâ€™, â€˜non-personalâ€™): not being, and never having been alive. grammatically, an inanimate noun or pronoun have noÂ referentÂ that includes a human, animal, plant or other entity which is considered alive.

inanimate whose

a fun thing to mention here is â€˜inanimate whoseâ€™ (whoseÂ inanimate,Â non-personalÂ whose, andÂ neuterÂ whose): whose indicates that the antecedent has aÂ possessiveÂ role in the relative clause (â€˜the manÂ whoseÂ daughter I marriedâ€™), but it can also refer to things as well as animate objects (â€˜I found a carÂ whoseÂ battery was deadâ€™); the use of the inanimateÂ whoseÂ dates from the 15th century, but since the 18th century has drawn criticism from those who considerÂ whoseÂ to be theÂ genitive (possessive)Â only of the relative pronounÂ whoÂ and therefore believe it should be restricted to personal antecedents.

the preferred substitute isÂ of which the, which I find clumsy and overly formal (as in â€˜thatâ€™s the carÂ of which theÂ alarm keeps waking us up at night.â€™). The Cambridge Grammar of the English LanguageÂ emphasises it is perfectly grammatical (â€˜genitivesÂ â€¦ are completely grammatical and by no means exceptionalâ€™, pp.Â 1049â€“1050).

examples:

I could a tale unfold whose lightest word / Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood, (HamletÂ I.v)

or

By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes / Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows. (Two Gentlemen of Verona,Â III.ii)

or

And they said; Goe to, let us build us a city and a tower,Â whoseÂ top may reach unto heaven, and let us make us a name, lest we be scattered abroad upon the face of the whole earth. (Genesis 11:4, KJV)

antecedents

â€˜antecedentsâ€™: an expression that gives its meaning to aÂ proformÂ (pronoun, pro-verb, pro-adverb, etc.). such as the her in â€˜tina did her homeworkâ€™, as the pronoun â€˜herâ€™ refers to and takes meaning from â€˜tinaâ€™.

entry.title: ğŸ˜¶ Some Late Thoughts
entry.content:
So soon tired!â€”how very lively was I,
When I played, frolicked and on sky did fly,
But now when I shall lie on bed and think,
All left were memories. And stars do blink,
At my weary eyes, which stared and gazed
At the heavenly bodies half-embraced:
That dwelled for aeons, older than Titans,
Older than we; the sky they enlightens,
Still changes its colours, but nought of me
Can alter myself, as strength cease to be,
On my body. O love thou art poor alas!
â€”But lo! Thou art the fortune I amass.
The blood and sweat I wept away today,
Makes the lady in dreams my singing fay.
entry.summary: So soon tired!â€”how very lively was I, When I played, frolicked and on sky did fly, But now when I shall lie on bed and think, All left were memories. And stars do blink, At my weary eyes, which stared and gazed At the heavenly bodies half-embraced: That dwelled for aeons, older than Titans, Older than we; the sky they enlightens, Still changes its colours, but nought of me Can alter myself, as strength cease to be, On my body. O love thou art poor alas! â€”But lo! Thou art the fortune I amass. The blood and sweat I wept away today, Makes the lady in dreams my singing fay.

entry.title: ğŸŒ Epitaph of a Tommy
entry.content:
I fumbled slowly through my silver case,
The silver case God gave me on that day
Of memories I had: I could not chase,
As they had fled by the heavenly bay.
I mocked the case. But wryly I did cry
For all the wealth, the fame, the fancy pride
Turned into nothingness. All others die:
The friends, the knowledge, the belovÃ¨d bride.
How sad I was? How quickly did the sky
Fade into nothingness too? And the stars
Laughed abrupt: as so weakly snivelled I,
For my memories lost; tingling my scars,
Of the harms I had done in prior years,
Of the harms which shed with my dropping tears.
entry.summary: I fumbled slowly through my silver case, The silver case God gave me on that day Of memories I had: I could not chase, As they had fled by the heavenly bay. I mocked the case. But wryly I did cry For all the wealth, the fame, the fancy pride Turned into nothingness. All others die: The friends, the knowledge, the belovÃ¨d bride. How sad I was? How quickly did the sky Fade into nothingness too? And the stars Laughed abrupt: as so weakly snivelled I, For my memories lost; tingling my scars, Of the harms I had done in prior years, Of the harms which shed with my dropping tears.

entry.title: âš°ï¸ Epitaph of the Past
entry.content:
Surely at last, the fairies, the damp moon,
Must leave its barrÃ¨d queendom; and now soon
Shall Love and song die hand in hand together,
Fade from the mainlands, from the mainstream coasts.
Look not, O Dryad, you who dwell unseen;
Look not, snapdragon, sunflower, sweet rose,
Behold not this world where Hera unqueenâ€™d:
Lest once again, we think of her depose.
Tender Romance! Thy winter drawing nigh,
Fey miracle! Dissolve in rigmarole;
O Dryad, the Nymphs! Dead and dust though thou art:
Take me, and whither would you take my soul?
entry.summary: Surely at last, the fairies, the damp moon, Must leave its barrÃ¨d queendom; and now soon Shall Love and song die hand in hand together, Fade from the mainlands, from the mainstream coasts. Look not, O Dryad, you who dwell unseen; Look not, snapdragon, sunflower, sweet rose, Behold not this world where Hera unqueenâ€™d: Lest once again, we think of her depose. Tender Romance! Thy winter drawing nigh, Fey miracle! Dissolve in rigmarole; O Dryad, the Nymphs! Dead and dust though thou art: Take me, and whither would you take my soul?
